awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Siberian Traps and the end-Permian Extinction: Coincidence and Causality

por.por_cntn:
The largest of all mass extinctions occurred at the end of the Permian Period, 252 million years ago. Although there have been many explanations of why this catastrophe occurred, current research links the event to the massive volcanic eruption of what are now called the Siberian Traps. Our work focused on interpreting the geologic record of carbon emissions from these volcanoes. We developed a computer model that calculated how much carbon dioxide needed to be released each year through this event to explain the large change we observe in the carbon isotopic composition of the ocean and atmosphere, as recorded in limestones. We found that rates of emissions waxed and waned over the hundred-thousand-year event, with peak emissions of about 1 billion tons of carbon per year. These emissions caused carbon dioxide levels to rise, and the geologic record confirms that global temperatures climbed to levels that likely were intolerable for most plants and animals living at the time. 

The warming also caused a reduction in the supply of oxygen to the ocean, leading to widespread "dead zones" and the development of regions of the ocean rich in toxic hydrogen sulfide. We were able to simulate this phenomenon with our models, and also document that the development of low oxygen conditions began abruptly at the onset of the extinction event.

This study thus provides a link between rapid carbon dioxide emissions, global warming, the spread of low oxygen "dead zones," and mass extinction. The Siberian Traps were a massive volcanic eruption, one of the largest in Earth history, yet our estimate of peak carbon dioxide emission rates are small compared to modern fossil fuel burning rates (approximate 10 billion tons of carbon a year).
